Mahoney Ignored
By Organization

L

By WILLIAM FATTEN
George Mahoney is no newcomer to politics. In the
past sixteen years he has made six attempts to gain
public office. His only conquest has been a seat on
the Maryland State Racing Commission, held in the
1.940's. A curiosity in the present election, (Mahoney's
Seventh), is that a man so enveloped by politics should
apparently lack an entourage of committed supporters.
tIowhem can we find the "Mahoney organization", the
*Mahoney men". His headquarters lack the starryeyed young girls folding letters and answering the
phone (it seldom rings). The billboard and bumper
Sticker advertisements are sparse. Testimonial banquets,
television appearances and rallies have been confined
to the Republicans.
Mahoney claims that he isn't running against another
candidate but against the present condition "of things".
Therefore he needs no political alliances or wham-bha.m
Campaigns."The great body politic knows where George
„Mahoney stands." One must wonder whether this is the
Case or was Mahoney left to fend for himself by the
embarrassed political chieftains.
Controls Districts
The most powerful political "boss" In Baltimore is
dames H. (Jack) Pollack. His "Trenton Democratic
Club" controls the Fourth and Fifth Districts in Baltimore City, and branches occasionally into contested
territory. He has manipulated elections, the Baltimore
City Council and an occasional judge for three decades.

pLuRYING. IN THE MAT

SPIRO T. AGNEW

GEORGE P. MAHONEY

Group Formed To Stop Mahoney;
Seeks Volunteers From Hopkins
By DENN-I ESTIS
"Democrats may have nominated for Governor one
of the worst racist bigots in the history of Maryland
politics." This opinion was expressed by James Reston,
veteran New York Times columnist, in his description
the Democratic candidate for governor, George P. Mahoney, on October 9.
Similar statements have been echoed by many diverse national organizations including the Americans
for Democratic Action, The New Republic, The Washington Post, and the New York Tines.
Towson State Demonstrations
Spurred on by recent racist demonstrations held by
the National States Rights Party and the Klu Klux
Klan at Towson State College in support of Mr. Mahoney, several concerned Johns Hopkins University
graduate studentsDemocrats, Republicans, and Independents—deciding that a Mahoney win was a distinct
possibility, formed an independent organization devoid
of the Republican and Democratic partisanship called
the Citizens To Stop Mahoney.
The new group's philosophy is to get every possible
voter out in a last determined move. William Dobelle,
a Hopkins graduate student in the biophysics department and coordinator of the organization, said that
"If there's a vote left, let's get it!"
Hopkins Students Needed
The Stop Mahoney group, in hoping to maintain a
one week sustained campaign, desires to enlist the help
of many Hopkins students in this fight. They are in
need of "warm bodies and willing workers," who will
achieve their three fold purpose.
First, the group mebers are attempting to get the
vote out in the City of Baltimore for Spiro T. Agnew,
Republican candidate for governor, pointing out the
fact that Carlton Sickles had been defeated by Mahoney in the primary by some 2,000 votes, or one vote
per Maryland precinct.
Too Late For Nine Changing
Secondly, the Stop Mahoney group realizes as Dobelle
says that "it is too late to start changing peoples'
minds. We are not planning to get anyone who plans to
vote for Mahoney to vote for Agnew. No time remains
1,0 go around changing peoples' minds." Instead they
are concern.ecl with running an all out effort designed
especially at 'those districts in the city where voting
was light during the primary and where many individuals, especially in the Negro population misinterpreted Mr. Mahoney's slogan that "Your Home Is Your
Castle."
Thirdly, the group hopes to incite an interest for
Agnew among Independent Gubernatorial candidate
Hyman Pressman's supporters, hoping to make them
realize the dangers which will result in the event of a
split vote including the possibility of a Mahoney victory with less than a voting majority.

The organization is urging that all interested persons
attend a special volunteers' meeting at the Charles
Theatre, 1711 N. Charles Street, on Saturday, October
29 at 10:00 P.M. Hopkins students are particularly encouraged as the results of this election will have definite
effects on the nation especially in the area of human
rights and politics. Among the various jobs to be performed include the canvassing of precincts—on and
before election day—making telephone calls, and working in the group's main headquarters at 25th Street
and Maryland Avenue.
The bipartisan Agnew supporters _decided to support
the Republican candidate over Mr. Pressman because
they felt that the former was "eminently qualified" for
the job, and the fact that as Republican organization
candidate he immediately starts out with three hundred
thousand votes and proper financial backing.
• Publicity Hound
In addition, they consider Pressman "a publicity
hound, not the kind of man you want for administrative chief of staff."
The Washington Post feels that "Mr. Pressman is
a decent and honest man, but he is not an acceptable
possibility fcl• the Governor's chair. He represents, in
general, an achronistic passion for low cost, low-tax
government with limited public services. His proposals
for legalized gambling and lotteries only open the
prospect for increased crime and the unhappy social
side-effects that Southern Maryland encountered with
its slot machines."
Policy Positions
Regarding the policy positions of the two major
candidates, Mahoney has, as cited in the Washington
Post, followed a policy • of "persistent refusal . . . to
talk about the State's real affairs." When he has taken
a stand, he completely evades the issues in regard to
the tax problem, transit, crime, and highway safety.
The Democratic candidate fails to say how or really
what he plans to do as governor. His only actual stand
has been on the question of open housing, which he is
completely against; but even in this area, he has shown
his lack of true knowledge of this complex issue?
Mahoney has been recognized as the bosses' candidates. He is particularly noted through his long but
unsuccessful political career as a follower and "yes"
man.
Preferable to Mahoney
Agnew, on the other hand, has taken definite stands
on all the primary issues confronting a state of Maryland's capabilities. He may not be considered a devout
liberal on the question of open housing, but his backing of the recently defeated civil rights bill is, as the
New York Times felt, "distinctly preferable to that of
Mr. Mahoney, whose nomination was largely attributable to a 'white backlash' vote."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCTOBER 28, 1966

kministration Explains Outlook
On Discrimination in Housing
The number of commercial and
private off-campus housing accommodations listed with the
University Housing Office in Wolman Hall has dropped from 482
in 1965 to a present total of 122,
according to Victor H. Dates,
Director of Special Programs at
Hopkins and administration advisor on civil rights.
This school year is the first in
which all private and commercial
landlords have been required to
sign a non-discrimination pledge
before being listed by the University. Over 600 accommodations
were listed several years ago before the establishment of a
pledge card system for all commercial landlords in 1964.
Position Clarified
In an effort to clarify the University's position on human
rights, following much agitation
by the Basic Freedoms Committee last November, Secretary
Ross Jones made public a letter
to officers, faculty, students, and
employees in December, 1965. He
endorsed the University's problems of complete non-discrimination at all levels of endeavor.
Within a month of the publication of Mr. Jones's letter, Dr.
Milton S. Eisenhower announced
the major change in pledge card
policies. In light of debates over
local open occupancy and charges
of discrimination, Dr. Eisenhower re-emphasized that the
University could not in good
conscience continue to list real
estate holdings of landlords
whose feelings did not coincide
with its own.
According to the rule, which
went into effect this fall, all
landlords wishing to be included
on the University list must sign
a pledge card stating that they
are in agreement with Hopkins'
non-discriminatory policies and
are willing to rent their property
without regard to race, creed or
national origin.
N-L Research
Recent News-Letter research
among a cross sampling of local
landlords located east of the
campus produced no evidence of
any discrimination. The paper
was aided in its research by sev-

DEAR REB:

Lately, every timel call my girl, she's either "not in" or "not interested." Last week I called her 23 times and couldn't even make a
coffee date. The trouble started when she started dating a guy
who owns a Dodge Coronet. Now she goes to parties with him,
dances, football games,etc. Do you think I should call her again,
or should I forget her and break her heart?
BAD CONNECTIONS
DEAR BAD CONNECTIONS:

I think your next call should be to your Dodge Dealer. Then make
a date to see the '67 Coronet, the car that's breaking hearts all
over America. You'll find that its good looks are pretty hard to
resist. Now, before you break your girl's heart, give her another
break. Ask her to go for a ride in your new Coronet. I think she'll
get the signal.

STOP MAHONEY
After five futile attempts, it appears that George
P. Mahoney is on the verge of succeeding in his perennial
quest for the governorship of Maryland.
Supported by the everpresent undercurrent of racial
prejudice and the recently generated swell of white backlash, the candidacy of Mahoney threatens to introduce
in to the State House the type of government reminiscent
of the Reconstruction era.
Unlike his two opponents, Mahoney has shown himself to be manifestly incapable of presenting_ a sound
program dealing with the issues of state finance, education, pollution control, and transportation. He has succeeded in obscuring these points through his emotional
appeals for closed housing, and the election will unfortunately hinge on the degree to which his philosophy
is shared by Maryland voters.
In an attempt to overcome Mahoney's apparent appeal to the public, a non-partisan "Citizens To Stop
Mahoney" organization has been formed. Its plan is to
go into Baltimore precincts where the turnout was light
in the primary, and to convince the residents to vote
against Mahoney by casting their ballots for the Republican candidate, Spiro T. Agnew.
In a state where a plurality of votes is sufficient for
election, Mahoney is conceded to have already amassed
the support of at least one-third of the electorate. Realizing that Independent Hyman Pressman's support is
woefully limited to the Baltimore area, the Stop Mahoney group is playing practical politics and supporting
Agnew. Pressman, who either does not grasp the full
meaning of the situation or is overcome with ambition,
adamantly refuses to withdraw his candidacy, a move
which would assure majority rule and give the voters a
clear choice.
In order to achieve its goal, the Stop Mahoney
organization needs volunteers, and has turned to Hopkins students to enlist their all. While we recopize that
the majority of students here are from out of town, we
still urge that Hopkins heed this request.
For one thing, the election has taken on national
implications. Indicative of this is Richard Nixon's recent observation that "the party of Jefferson, Jackson,
and Wilson has become the party of Maddox, Mahoney,
and Wallace."
As a border state, Maryland becomes an important
barometer for the fortunes of the enforcement of basic
civil rights. While northern politicians may ignore the
election of Wallace or Maddox, Alahoney's election would
serve to restrain enthusiastic furtherance of civil rights.
There is yet a more compelling reason. To any student who believes that knowledge must supplant
prejudice and that freedom should breed responsibility,
the candidacy of Mahoney is as gross an insult to him
as to the Maryland body politic. For Hopkins to remain
passive in this election is to allow Veritas Vos Liberabit
to be cruelly mocked by "Your Home Is Your Castle."
One need only consider his reaction were Mahoney
running for governor in his own state. That he is doing
so in Maryland seems to us to be no less a catastrophe
than if he were a candidate in Pennsylvania or New York.
"The actions of men," wrote John Locke, "are
the hest interpreters of their thoughts." In volunteering
to aid the Stop Mahoney group, Hopkins students have
the opportunity to play a significant role in the outcome
of the election, remaining loyal, at least, to the concepts
for which the University stands. Should Mahoney be
elected, no one will ever mistake the government of
Free State as the embodiment of Truth.

CANUCK! CANUCK!
Among its many interests the News-Letter takes it
upon itself to keep tabs on its brother student publications at Hopkins. We note with a mixture of superiority
and shame the failure of the current edition of the
Hullabaloo to keep pace with new standards of Journalistic endeavor undertaken by the News-Letter, Vector,
and Charles Street Review.
We might certainly agree that the 1965 Hullabaloo
was a hard act to follow. It combined a new size and
creative layout with a high standard of photography to
produce the most memorably excellent yearbook in the
recorded history of yearbooks.
Nevertheless for the editors of the 1966 Hullabaloo
to attempt to erase the fine memory of their predecessor
by producing 200 pages of cliche was as disappointing as
it was dull.
This, however, is no reason not to pick it up since
most of you have already paid for it and next year is
another year as tomorrow is another day, or something
like that.

Sotir lids called Parthemore an

In his new book, THE ACCIDENTAL CENTURY, Michael Harrington examines the cultural
and intellectual crisis confronting the United States and the rest of the Western world
in the 20th century. This crisis has been brought about by the "accidental revolution,"
in which an unplanned social and creative technology has haphazardly reshaped our
lives and put in doubt all our ideologies and beliefs. The resulting decadence threatens
to destroy Western civilization and with it the Western concept of man.

'Cagey' Hobart Here
For Sat. Grid Test
By MIKE PHILLIPS
After showing increased spark
despite a one-sided loss, the
varsity football team gets some
tough and interesting opposition
tomorrow when it faces Hobart
here at 2:00 P.M.
The New York squad. 2-3
against opponents slightly
rougher than those to which the
Jays are accustomed, uses a
wide variety of offensive and defensive sets. If nothing else, Hobart should give Homewood fans
an augmented appreciation of
football's strategic intracacies.
Most of this collegiate unorthodoxy can be observed when
the defensive unit takes the field.
Frosh coach Bob Scott, who
scouted Hobart, reports that it
displays a wild variety of defensive formations, makes liberal
use of an equally great amount
of stunts and blitzes, and by virtue of its aggressive gambling
style is virtually impossible to
anticipate.
I Formation
The offense is somewhat more
normal, utilizing an I formation
in which a blocking back is usually set between guard and tackle, but can be postioned as a
flanker.
Setbaks in the I are 5-8 168
pound Mark Perkins, who made
the Eastern Collegiate Athletic
Conference's All Star Team when
he went for 135 yards on 22 carries against Hamilton, and 5-8,

172 pound Tom Morley. Quarterback Mike Hanna (171 yards
passing in a 7-6 win over Union)
leads an excellent air attack and
has an inviting target in 6-2, 182
pound speedster Bill Breck.
Some Improvement
Despite a 28-0 pasting last
week at the hands of a strong
(Continued on Page 6)

Tough Breaks
In the frustrating loss to the
Diplomats, Hopkins outshot F&M
24-13. The players executed drilling techniques exactly. The Jays
were beating them at midfield
constantly and kept the pressure
on throughout the entire game.
They were in F&M territory so
frequently that the players jammed up in front of the goal and
they never had very clear shots.
Against Delaware, Hopkins
clearly controlled the offense
taking 27 shots to Delaware's 12.
Yet, they lost 2-1. Kit Batenfeld
was the only Bluejay able to
score. Pablo Drobny, the team's
top scorer, has been slowed down
by a painful ankle injury in the
past two games.
Maintaining their confidence
will be Hopkins' toughest.job in

facing Loyola tomorrow. In the
past two games, the Jays have
taken over fifty shots at the
goal with only one score. Hopefully their luck will change for
the better tomorrow. The Greyhounds are a much improved
team this year and are in an
upswing. They are favorites in
this contest because of their 4-3
record and well-played loss to
Baltimore University, 3-2. B.U.
in a pre-season scrimmage defeated Hopkins 4-6.
Loyola Scouted
The Loyola squad is sparked
by the superior play of veteran
halfbacks, Bob Szcapniack and
Harry Biedronski. Hopkins defeated Loyola last year 5-3 in a
wide.open game, but they should
have their hands full tomorrow.
The Bluejays will probably attempt to diversify their attack
by mixing up the offensive a
little and by kicking some long
shots.

SPIRO T. AGNEW

GEORGE P. MAHONEY

Group Formed To Stop Mahoney;
Seeks Volunteers From Hopkins
By DENN-I ESTIS
"Democrats may have nominated for Governor one
of the worst racist bigots in the history of Maryland
politics." This opinion was expressed by James Reston,
veteran New York Times columnist, in his description
the Democratic candidate for governor, George P. Mahoney, on October 9.
Similar statements have been echoed by many diverse national organizations including the Americans
for Democratic Action, The New Republic, The Washington Post, and the New York Tines.
Towson State Demonstrations
Spurred on by recent racist demonstrations held by
the National States Rights Party and the Klu Klux
Klan at Towson State College in support of Mr. Mahoney, several concerned Johns Hopkins University
graduate studentsDemocrats, Republicans, and Independents—deciding that a Mahoney win was a distinct
possibility, formed an independent organization devoid
of the Republican and Democratic partisanship called
the Citizens To Stop Mahoney.
The new group's philosophy is to get every possible
voter out in a last determined move. William Dobelle,
a Hopkins graduate student in the biophysics department and coordinator of the organization, said that
"If there's a vote left, let's get it!"
Hopkins Students Needed
The Stop Mahoney group, in hoping to maintain a
one week sustained campaign, desires to enlist the help
of many Hopkins students in this fight. They are in
need of "warm bodies and willing workers," who will
achieve their three fold purpose.
First, the group mebers are attempting to get the
vote out in the City of Baltimore for Spiro T. Agnew,
Republican candidate for governor, pointing out the
fact that Carlton Sickles had been defeated by Mahoney in the primary by some 2,000 votes, or one vote
per Maryland precinct.
Too Late For Nine Changing
Secondly, the Stop Mahoney group realizes as Dobelle
says that "it is too late to start changing peoples'
minds. We are not planning to get anyone who plans to
vote for Mahoney to vote for Agnew. No time remains
1,0 go around changing peoples' minds." Instead they
are concern.ecl with running an all out effort designed
especially at 'those districts in the city where voting
was light during the primary and where many individuals, especially in the Negro population misinterpreted Mr. Mahoney's slogan that "Your Home Is Your
Castle."
Thirdly, the group hopes to incite an interest for
Agnew among Independent Gubernatorial candidate
Hyman Pressman's supporters, hoping to make them
realize the dangers which will result in the event of a
split vote including the possibility of a Mahoney victory with less than a voting majority.

The organization is urging that all interested persons
attend a special volunteers' meeting at the Charles
Theatre, 1711 N. Charles Street, on Saturday, October
29 at 10:00 P.M. Hopkins students are particularly encouraged as the results of this election will have definite
effects on the nation especially in the area of human
rights and politics. Among the various jobs to be performed include the canvassing of precincts—on and
before election day—making telephone calls, and working in the group's main headquarters at 25th Street
and Maryland Avenue.
The bipartisan Agnew supporters _decided to support
the Republican candidate over Mr. Pressman because
they felt that the former was "eminently qualified" for
the job, and the fact that as Republican organization
candidate he immediately starts out with three hundred
thousand votes and proper financial backing.
• Publicity Hound
In addition, they consider Pressman "a publicity
hound, not the kind of man you want for administrative chief of staff."
The Washington Post feels that "Mr. Pressman is
a decent and honest man, but he is not an acceptable
possibility fcl• the Governor's chair. He represents, in
general, an achronistic passion for low cost, low-tax
government with limited public services. His proposals
for legalized gambling and lotteries only open the
prospect for increased crime and the unhappy social
side-effects that Southern Maryland encountered with
its slot machines."
Policy Positions
Regarding the policy positions of the two major
candidates, Mahoney has, as cited in the Washington
Post, followed a policy • of "persistent refusal . . . to
talk about the State's real affairs." When he has taken
a stand, he completely evades the issues in regard to
the tax problem, transit, crime, and highway safety.
The Democratic candidate fails to say how or really
what he plans to do as governor. His only actual stand
has been on the question of open housing, which he is
completely against; but even in this area, he has shown
his lack of true knowledge of this complex issue?
Mahoney has been recognized as the bosses' candidates. He is particularly noted through his long but
unsuccessful political career as a follower and "yes"
man.
Preferable to Mahoney
Agnew, on the other hand, has taken definite stands
on all the primary issues confronting a state of Maryland's capabilities. He may not be considered a devout
liberal on the question of open housing, but his backing of the recently defeated civil rights bill is, as the
New York Times felt, "distinctly preferable to that of
Mr. Mahoney, whose nomination was largely attributable to a 'white backlash' vote."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, OCTOBER 28, 1966

kministration Explains Outlook
On Discrimination in Housing
The number of commercial and
private off-campus housing accommodations listed with the
University Housing Office in Wolman Hall has dropped from 482
in 1965 to a present total of 122,
according to Victor H. Dates,
Director of Special Programs at
Hopkins and administration advisor on civil rights.
This school year is the first in
which all private and commercial
landlords have been required to
sign a non-discrimination pledge
before being listed by the University. Over 600 accommodations
were listed several years ago before the establishment of a
pledge card system for all commercial landlords in 1964.
Position Clarified
In an effort to clarify the University's position on human
rights, following much agitation
by the Basic Freedoms Committee last November, Secretary
Ross Jones made public a letter
to officers, faculty, students, and
employees in December, 1965. He
endorsed the University's problems of complete non-discrimination at all levels of endeavor.
Within a month of the publication of Mr. Jones's letter, Dr.
Milton S. Eisenhower announced
the major change in pledge card
policies. In light of debates over
local open occupancy and charges
of discrimination, Dr. Eisenhower re-emphasized that the
University could not in good
conscience continue to list real
estate holdings of landlords
whose feelings did not coincide
with its own.

went into effect this fall, all

STOP MAHONEY
After five futile attempts, it appears that George
P. Mahoney is on the verge of succeeding in his perennial
quest for the governorship of Maryland.
Supported by the everpresent undercurrent of racial
prejudice and the recently generated swell of white backlash, the candidacy of Mahoney threatens to introduce
in to the State House the type of government reminiscent
of the Reconstruction era.
Unlike his two opponents, Mahoney has shown himself to be manifestly incapable of presenting_ a sound
program dealing with the issues of state finance, education, pollution control, and transportation. He has succeeded in obscuring these points through his emotional
appeals for closed housing, and the election will unfortunately hinge on the degree to which his philosophy
is shared by Maryland voters.
In an attempt to overcome Mahoney's apparent appeal to the public, a non-partisan "Citizens To Stop
Mahoney" organization has been formed. Its plan is to
go into Baltimore precincts where the turnout was light
in the primary, and to convince the residents to vote
against Mahoney by casting their ballots for the Republican candidate, Spiro T. Agnew.
In a state where a plurality of votes is sufficient for
election, Mahoney is conceded to have already amassed
the support of at least one-third of the electorate. Realizing that Independent Hyman Pressman's support is
woefully limited to the Baltimore area, the Stop Mahoney group is playing practical politics and supporting
Agnew. Pressman, who either does not grasp the full
meaning of the situation or is overcome with ambition,
adamantly refuses to withdraw his candidacy, a move
which would assure majority rule and give the voters a
clear choice.
In order to achieve its goal, the Stop Mahoney
organization needs volunteers, and has turned to Hopkins students to enlist their all. While we recopize that
the majority of students here are from out of town, we
still urge that Hopkins heed this request.
For one thing, the election has taken on national
implications. Indicative of this is Richard Nixon's recent observation that "the party of Jefferson, Jackson,
and Wilson has become the party of Maddox, Mahoney,
and Wallace."
As a border state, Maryland becomes an important
barometer for the fortunes of the enforcement of basic
civil rights. While northern politicians may ignore the
election of Wallace or Maddox, Alahoney's election would
serve to restrain enthusiastic furtherance of civil rights.
There is yet a more compelling reason. To any student who believes that knowledge must supplant
prejudice and that freedom should breed responsibility,
the candidacy of Mahoney is as gross an insult to him
as to the Maryland body politic. For Hopkins to remain
passive in this election is to allow Veritas Vos Liberabit
to be cruelly mocked by "Your Home Is Your Castle."
One need only consider his reaction were Mahoney
running for governor in his own state. That he is doing
so in Maryland seems to us to be no less a catastrophe
than if he were a candidate in Pennsylvania or New York.
"The actions of men," wrote John Locke, "are
the hest interpreters of their thoughts." In volunteering
to aid the Stop Mahoney group, Hopkins students have
the opportunity to play a significant role in the outcome
of the election, remaining loyal, at least, to the concepts
for which the University stands. Should Mahoney be
elected, no one will ever mistake the government of
Free State as the embodiment of Truth.

CANUCK! CANUCK!
Among its many interests the News-Letter takes it
upon itself to keep tabs on its brother student publications at Hopkins. We note with a mixture of superiority
and shame the failure of the current edition of the
Hullabaloo to keep pace with new standards of Journalistic endeavor undertaken by the News-Letter, Vector,
and Charles Street Review.
We might certainly agree that the 1965 Hullabaloo
was a hard act to follow. It combined a new size and
creative layout with a high standard of photography to
produce the most memorably excellent yearbook in the
recorded history of yearbooks.
Nevertheless for the editors of the 1966 Hullabaloo
to attempt to erase the fine memory of their predecessor
by producing 200 pages of cliche was as disappointing as
it was dull.
This, however, is no reason not to pick it up since
most of you have already paid for it and next year is
another year as tomorrow is another day, or something
like that.

'Cagey' Hobart Here
For Sat. Grid Test
By MIKE PHILLIPS
After showing increased spark
despite a one-sided loss, the
varsity football team gets some
tough and interesting opposition
tomorrow when it faces Hobart
here at 2:00 P.M.
The New York squad. 2-3
against opponents slightly
rougher than those to which the
Jays are accustomed, uses a
wide variety of offensive and defensive sets. If nothing else, Hobart should give Homewood fans
an augmented appreciation of
football's strategic intracacies.
Most of this collegiate unorthodoxy can be observed when
the defensive unit takes the field.
Frosh coach Bob Scott, who
scouted Hobart, reports that it
displays a wild variety of defensive formations, makes liberal
use of an equally great amount
of stunts and blitzes, and by virtue of its aggressive gambling
style is virtually impossible to
anticipate.
I Formation
The offense is somewhat more
normal, utilizing an I formation
in which a blocking back is usually set between guard and tackle, but can be postioned as a
flanker.
Setbaks in the I are 5-8 168
pound Mark Perkins, who made
the Eastern Collegiate Athletic
Conference's All Star Team when
he went for 135 yards on 22 carries against Hamilton, and 5-8,

172 pound Tom Morley. Quarterback Mike Hanna (171 yards
passing in a 7-6 win over Union)
leads an excellent air attack and
has an inviting target in 6-2, 182
pound speedster Bill Breck.
Some Improvement
Despite a 28-0 pasting last
week at the hands of a strong

Tough Breaks
In the frustrating loss to the
Diplomats, Hopkins outshot F&M
24-13. The players executed drilling techniques exactly. The Jays
were beating them at midfield
constantly and kept the pressure
on throughout the entire game.
They were in F&M territory so
frequently that the players jammed up in front of the goal and
they never had very clear shots.
Against Delaware, Hopkins
clearly controlled the offense
taking 27 shots to Delaware's 12.
Yet, they lost 2-1. Kit Batenfeld
was the only Bluejay able to
score. Pablo Drobny, the team's
top scorer, has been slowed down
by a painful ankle injury in the
past two games.
Maintaining their confidence
will be Hopkins' toughest.job in

facing Loyola tomorrow. In the
past two games, the Jays have
taken over fifty shots at the
goal with only one score. Hopefully their luck will change for
the better tomorrow. The Greyhounds are a much improved
team this year and are in an
upswing. They are favorites in
this contest because of their 4-3
record and well-played loss to
Baltimore University, 3-2. B.U.
in a pre-season scrimmage defeated Hopkins 4-6.
Loyola Scouted
The Loyola squad is sparked
by the superior play of veteran
halfbacks, Bob Szcapniack and
Harry Biedronski. Hopkins defeated Loyola last year 5-3 in a
wide.open game, but they should
have their hands full tomorrow.
The Bluejays will probably attempt to diversify their attack
by mixing up the offensive a
little and by kicking some long
shots.
